item.title: Older Australians waiting longer to access home support services | SBS News In Easy English 30 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Drowning victims' families 'in shock' but grateful after $150k raised in support
item.description: Over $150,000 has been raised to support the families of two men who drowned in NSW, as their communities grapple with loss.

item.title: Is it too late to fix your mortgage interest rate? & Trump ready to announce Fed Chair pick
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Canstar's Sally Tindall to find out if it is too late to fix your home loan interest rate ahead of what's expected to be a rise in official interest rates next week; plus Dianne Colledge from Morgans goes through the day's share market action including a preview of Donald Trump's pick of US Federal Reserve governor which is expected to be made at the weekend.

item.title: Leader in dementia research shares four ways you can reduce your risk
item.description: Henry Brodaty is a world-recognised dementia researcher. Here, he shares ways you can seek to reduce your risk of developing the disease.

item.title: Australian beef farmers scramble to find new markets as a billion-dollar export hit looms
item.description: New tariffs on Australian beef may cut exports to China by 30 per cent cut this year, according to industry experts. Among those affected is a fifth-generation cattle farmer.

item.title: Should Australia rethink its alliance with the United States?
item.description: As Donald Trump’s military threats and trade wars unsettle allies, some experts are calling for a rethinking of Australia's long-standing alliance with the United States. The debate has been sharpened by Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney’s speech at the World Economic Forum, which urged middle power countries to resist compromising their values at the behest of major global superpowers.

item.title: Israel announces Gaza's Rafah border crossing with Egypt to reopen
item.description: Reopening of the crossing was one of the requirements under a US-brokered ceasefire agreed in October between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: The $1 billion problem facing Aussie farmers like Robert
item.description: A fifth-generation NSW farmer is among those 'shocked and disappointed' over new China tariffs on Australian beef.

item.title: 'Protect every solitary moment': The viral app that asks users if they're still alive
item.description: A popular Chinese app aims to address the issue of 'empty nesters' who die and are only found days, weeks, or even months later.

item.title: Thousands applied for this world-first visa. Now the first have arrived in Australia
item.description: Nearly 300 Tuvaluans can relocate to Australia each year under a new treaty, which was partially designed to assist those affected by climate change.

item.title: Working no longer 'number one': How this country is trying to break its overwork habit
item.description: While working hours have fallen and reforms are in place, Japan is still wrestling with a deep-rooted culture of overwork.

item.title: Exhibition described as a milestone for inclusion and representation
item.description: A powerful exhibition featuring photographs and stories of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with disability has been called a milestone for inclusion and representation. First exhibited at the United Nations in Geneva more than a decade ago, it's now being shown again on home soil in its most accessible format.

item.title: Second woman claims Epstein sent her to the UK for sex with former prince Andrew
item.description: The claims have emerged after newly-released Epstein files include images of the former prince crouching over an unidentified woman lying on the floor.

item.title: Reyna and her family are facing deportation from Australia. Her community is fighting back
item.description: A Queensland family, who have lived in Toowoomba for 14 years, are facing possible deportation from Australia — a visa battle that's caught the attention of their community.

item.title: My daughter might have hundreds of half-siblings. For this, I feel immense guilt
item.description: Carol's two children were conceived with donor sperm in the late 90s. Decades later, she and her family found out the whole truth.

item.title: Reopening of Gaza's Rafah border crossing expected on Monday, Israel says
item.description: Preparations are underway to open the crossing between Egypt and the Palestinian territory, which was closed in May 2024.

item.title: Grammys 2026: Bad Bunny makes history, Tame Impala secures sole Australian win
item.description: Several artists used their acceptance speeches to speak out against US President Donald Trump's immigration crackdown.

item.title: Ayatollah Khamenei warns Trump of broader conflict as the US amasses forces in the region
item.description: Iran's Supreme Leader is warning the United States that any attack on Iran could trigger regional conflict, as US naval presence in the region strengthens. As tensions mount over Iran's protest crackdown and a possible nuclear deal, the United States President says his plans hinge on the success or failure of a deal.

item.title: Australia confirms closure of Afghan embassy amid Taliban pressure
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has confirmed plans to close the Afghan Embassy in Australia, leaving many members of Australia's Afghan community on edge. Experts say the decision follows a demand from the Taliban that all embassies under the control of an anti-Taliban ambassador be closed. While some members of the Afghan diaspora in Australia say they expect the closure to have little impact, for others, it's a deeply concerning development.

item.title: Australia's top political spenders revealed | SBS News In Easy English 2 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Politicians' kids, billionaires and delivery giants: Australia's political donors revealed
item.description: Here's who donated the most in the lead-up to the 2025 federal election.

item.title: Property values accelerate ahead of RBA meeting & gold and silver prices smashed
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Tim Lawless from Cotality Australia about the future for property prices amid expectations of a rise in interest rates; Phil O'Donaghoe from Deutsche Bank explains why a rate rise tomorrow isn't a done deal; plus Raymond Chan from Morgans Financial Limited looks at the day's market action including a spectacular fall in the price of precious metals like gold and silver.

item.title: 'Lifeline' or 'poisoned chalice'? What the reopening of Gaza's Rafah crossing means
item.description: The "key transit route" has partially reopened after almost two years.

item.title: What could disappear if rates rise today — and how much a hike would cost you
item.description: You won't find this home loan rate if the RBA hikes, a finance expert says. But some economists believe a hold is still possible.

item.title: The Rafah crossing reopens, but with limited numbers
item.description: The Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt has been reopened. Movement will be limited, but for Palestinians needing medical treatment it offers a critical lifeline. The border has been largely shut since May 2024.

item.title: First Palestinians leave Gaza for medical treatment after Rafah crossing partially reopens
item.description: About 150 people were due to leave Gaza on the first day of the reopening, Egyptian officials said.

item.title: Royals, power and public trust: the Epstein files continue to rock the Establishment
item.description: From London to Oslo, institutions built on tradition and public trust are being tested by demands for transparency, accountability and justice. In Britain, both a former prince and a senior political figure are being urged to answer questions about their past associations with Jeffrey Epstein. While in Norway, a criminal trial involving the Crown Princess’s son is unfolding under intense public scrutiny.

item.title: Wong condemns 'horrific use of violence' as Australia imposes fresh sanctions on Iran
item.description: Australia has imposed new sanctions on 20 Iranian individuals and three entities, citing repression and human rights abuses.

item.title: School staff face termination under new hate speech rules | SBS News In Easy English 3 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Interest rate rise ends two-year pause
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia has ended a two-year hiatus by raising interest rates to 15 per cent, sparking a fierce political debate over whether government spending or private demand is fuelling persistent inflation. While the Treasurer defends the budget and points to external pressures, the Opposition and the Greens argue that current policy settings are punishing everyday Australians and ignoring alternative economic levers.

item.title: The key to a long life? One factor may matter more than we thought
item.description: Some say the study's findings have "important consequences for ageing research", while others believe they are "not too surprising".

item.title: RBA pulls the trigger on rates; gold and silver rebound
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia has increased interest rates for the first time since November 2023, hiking the official cash rate to 3.85%. It says it now expects inflation to remain well above its 2-3% target for longer, leaving the door open for further rate increases. For more on this, Stephanie Youssef spoke with HSBC chief economist Paul Bloxham. Despite the decision, the Australian share market finished the session strong, amid a strong global stocks rebound that included a gold and silver price recovery. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner, CEO at MPC Markets.

item.title: RBA governor's four reasons for rate hike as major banks react to increase
item.description: The Reserve Bank has hiked the cash rate to 3.85 per cent, with one of the major banks saying it's unlikely to be a "one-and-done".

item.title: 'The digital Wild West': Spain planning to ban social media for under-16s
item.description: Australia became the first country in the world to ban social media for under-16s last year.

item.title: The Australians competing in skimo, a new Olympic sport so steep athletes get 'delirious'
item.description: Two Australians will represent the country in the new sport at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games 2026.

item.title: 'Left out': How hate laws leave LGBTIQ+ workers vulnerable
item.description: Nearly half of Australia's LGBTIQ+ workers say they have faced discrimination and harassment in the past year. With hate speech rising in Australia, rights groups say stronger laws and greater legal representation are needed to protect the LGBTIQ+ community from greater harm.

item.title: Nearly nine billion a year: The 'particularly nasty' litter polluting Australia
item.description: Clean Up Australia's annual survey revealed this pervasive source of waste unseated soft plastics as the most prevalent item tossed on the ground.

item.title: Safety arrangements ahead of Herzog visit | SBS News In Easy English 4 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Russia blasts an end to the winter truce with Ukraine
item.description: Russia has ended a winter truce that had it and Ukraine agreeing not to attack each other's energy facilities. The 450-drone and 70-missiles attack comes on the eve of another scheduled round of peace talks.

item.title: Billionaire Clive Palmer to challenge electoral donations cap in High Court
item.description: Palmer's mining company, Mineralogy, funnelled more than $52 million into his party ahead of the federal election.

item.title: Capital Gains Tax again under the spotlight following latest rate rise
item.description: Following the latest interest rate rise, the Federal Government is facing renewed pressure from unions and economists to reform the 50 per cent Capital Gains Tax ((CGT)) discount, which critics label a "tax avoidance scheme" favouring the wealthiest Australians. While the Treasurer maintains a focus on housing supply, proponents of the reform argue that winding back these concessions could reclaim $20 billion in annual revenue and ease the cost-of-living crisis for the nation’s workforce.

item.title: Kids in jail, rising racism: Australia's 2026 human rights report card
item.description: Human Rights Watch has released its annual report for 2026, highlighting several issues it says have tarred Australia's reputation.

item.title: Kids in jail, rising racism: Australia's 2026 human rights report card
item.description: Human Rights Watch has released its annual report for 2026, highlighting several issues it says have tarred Australia's reputation.

item.title: Mapped: The $3 billion in defence sites the government wants to offload
item.description: The Opposition has accused the government of selling the "heart and soul" of Australia's defence force.

item.title: What's really driving inflation — and why software shares are getting crushed
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP to figure out the real drivers of inflation; plus Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action including a software shares sell-off.

item.title: Who is Isaac Herzog, and why is his imminent Australian visit controversial?
item.description: Israel's president is set to arrive in Australia soon for a visit hailed by some as "deeply significant", and criticised by others.

item.title: Many Aussies live in multi-generational homes. How is living with parents in your 40s?
item.description: While multi-generational living can come with a lot of benefits, others say most of our houses simply aren't designed for it.

item.title: What's behind Australia's inflation problem — and can you do anything about it?
item.description: Inflation is back in the spotlight after the Reserve Bank hiked rates for the first time in more than two years.

item.title: Trump administration to remove 700 immigration officers from Minnesota
item.description: Minneapolis has become a major flashpoint in Trump's immigration crackdown after two fatal shootings in the city by federal agents.

item.title: Mildura has already broken heatwave records. As climate change advances, what comes next?
item.description: For many in Australia's south-east, the day after Australia Day brought sweltering conditions and record temperatures. In Mildura, in Victoria's far northwest, the mercury hit 48.6 Celsius. And when coastal areas enjoyed a reprieve, the inland still had to cope with an extended heatwave that lasted a week. Experts say these kinds of phenomena are going to intensify over time because of the impacts of climate change - but while there has been plenty of coverage of how that impacts on urban centres, regional Australia has not received the same attention. SBS visited Mildura to see how the region felt the heat, and what they're doing to cope with climate change at a local level.

item.title: Coroner hands down inquest findings into Bondi mass stabbing | SBS News In Easy English 5 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Police say a suspect has been identified in the disappearance of four-year-old Gus Lamont
item.description: The four-year-old was reported missing from a remote South Australian sheep station in September.

item.title: Trump v Iran, the huge Epstein dump and Melania’s hundred-million-dollar doco bomb
item.description: The US and Iran tussle over talks to stave off more strikes, millions more Epstein documents touch the rich and powerful the world over from Elon Musk to the Norwegian princess-royal and more trilateral talks in Abu Dhabi don’t stop the destruction across Ukraine. Plus, US democracy in danger and what we learned when Melania Trump’s doco hit the cinemas…

item.title: Who's using the capital gains tax discount, and how much does it cost the budget?
item.description: A rise in the cash rate due to stubborn inflation has cast a spotlight on making housing more affordable.

item.title: The cost of cancer: new research highlights the financial toll of treatment
item.description: Almost 99 per cent of Australians diagnosed with cancer incur out-of-pocket expenses, even when accessing public care. That's the shocking finding from the Cancer Council Australia’s latest national survey, which suggests the financial burden arises from both direct medical costs and indirect expenses at every stage of the cancer journey. The cost of accessing care and treatment hits First Nations communities especially hard, with Indigenous Australians ultimately facing a higher mortality rate for blood cancer.

item.title: Democracy is under threat warns Human Rights Watch, set back to the 1980s
item.description: Democracy and the rules-based international order are under threat, according to the latest annual report by Human Rights Watch. There's a particular focus on the United States and what the international body describes as its erosion of human rights, but there is also a spotlight on Australia. Australia's immigration and youth detention policies are listed as 'significant failings', cited as the only Western democracy without a national human rights act.

item.title: 'Might be how I die': Nick nearly didn't survive a Japan ski trip. He's now warning travellers
item.description: An Australian who had a near-fatal ski accident in Japan has urged holidaymakers to be aware of risks, following recent deaths.

item.title: Software sell-off continues and bitcoin tumbles
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Ben Clark from TMS Private Wealth about the day's market action including a software sell-off in the US which is trickling to Australia, plus what the fall in the bitcoin price says about the economic and investment environment.

item.title: AFP confirms it won't arrest Israeli President Isaac Herzog amid calls for investigation
item.description: The Australian Federal Police has confirmed it has sought independent legal advice about how to handle the president of Israel's upcoming visit to Australia.

item.title: 'Dangerous, sick and hopeless situation': Fears after US-Russia nuclear control deal expires
item.description: Experts say the expiry of an arms control treaty between the US and Russia is "the end of an era".

item.title: Russia and Ukraine conduct first prisoner swap in months amid peace talks in Abu Dhabi
item.description: The countries swapped 157 captured soldiers and civilians each after US-mediated peace talks.

item.title: Prisoners of war exchanged, with hope of further Russia-Ukraine peace talks
item.description: A second round of talks in Abu Dhabi between Ukraine, Russia and the United States have concluded without a peace deal, despite delegates citing progress towards reaching an end to the four-year war. Ukraine and Russia did exchange 310 prisoners of war in total, as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy signalled further meetings were being planned.

item.title: Turf war: Why this median strip conflict is being compared to the division of Korea
item.description: An inner-city median strip has become the centre of a row a mayor likened to a geopolitical standoff.

item.title: PM travels to Indonesia to sign security treaty | SBS News In Easy English 6 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Pressure mounts on Keir Starmer to resign over Epstein scandal
item.description: The UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is under mounting pressure, following scrutiny over his decision to appoint friend of Jeffrey Epstein Peter Mandelson as the UK's US ambassador in 2024. The files released last week included emails appearing to show a close relationship between the former ambassador and Epstein, and suggested Mr Mandelson had shared government documents with Epstein while serving as a Cabinet Minister.

item.title: 'Impossible choices': The data that proves living costs are rising for Australians
item.description: Living costs rose across all households over the past year, with those on government payments facing the steepest increases.

item.title: Family 'devastated': A timeline of Gus Lamont's disappearance and major crime investigation
item.description: Police recently revealed they had identified a suspect who was living at the remote property at the time Gus vanished.

item.title: ASX200's worst day since April 2025 as technology rout continues
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Lochlan Halloway from Morningstar to go through all the factors that has triggered a sell-off on the sharemarket, including an ongoing technology sector rout, along with a look at the local reporting season; plus Peter McGuire from Trading.com looks at Bitcoin's sliding value.

item.title: Do you earn more or less than others working in the same job?
item.description: New figures show where the highest-paid Australian workers live and what jobs they are doing.

item.title: Tutorials, work and fears their loved ones are dead: The uni students facing unique stress
item.description: 'Aida' is among university students from Iran battling financial stress and emotional trauma, following the recent violent crackdown.

item.title: ‘Are our loved ones alive or not?’ A distressing start to the academic year for these international students
item.description: University students in Australia, including more than 800,000 from overseas, are preparing for a new academic year. However, many from Iran are facing financial hardship while also grieving lives lost during recent protests.

item.title: Russian general under US sanctions shot several times in Moscow
item.description: Investigators said lieutenant general Vladimir Alexeyev was critically injured after he was shot by an unidentified gunman.

item.title: INTERVIEW: SBS talks to Mildura's mayor on managing heatwaves, and overcoming climate change scepticism
item.description: The far northwestern city of Mildura is used to hot summers. But in January, the city and surrounds sweltered through an unusual heatwave, with temperatures breaking records throughout the region. SBS' Deborah Groarke spoke with the mayor of Mildura, Ali Cupper, on how the Council deals with hot weather, and its concerns around how worsening climate change patterns might affect its residents and agricultural economy.

item.title: In pictures: Twin flames and message of unity open Milano Cortina Winter Olympics
item.description: Mariah Carey, Milan-born rapper Ghali and Italian pop star Laura Pausini were among the headline performers at Milan's San Siro stadium.

item.title: Minns invokes special powers, urges calm ahead of Israeli president's visit
item.description: The NSW premier said special provisions invoked for Isaac Herzog's visit were about public safety and not a ban on lawful protests.

item.title: Iran says US nuclear talks off to 'good start' but draws line at missile, proxy issues
item.description: Iran's top diplomat struck an optimistic note after talks on its nuclear program, despite US pressure to broaden the agenda.

item.title: From SoundCloud to the Super Bowl — Bad Bunny set to make halftime history
item.description: The Puerto Rican star will be the first Latin artist to perform solo at America's most-viewed concert.

item.title: 'You cannot escape diversity': The controversial housing laws trying to 'integrate' immigrants
item.description: Denmark's once-termed "ghetto laws" were designed to "integrate" immigrants but the European Court of Justice has deemed them potentially unlawful.

item.title: The Trump effect and 90s nostalgia: What's behind the rise in 'Chinamaxxing'?
item.description: A Chinamaxxing trend has emerged on social media with creators posting about being in a "very Chinese time of my life".

item.title: Trump's America wants more access to your personal data. Could the Australian Government hand it over?
item.description: Growing speculation over a proposal to hand Australians' personal and biometric data to the United States is raising alarm among privacy and security experts. As other countries with visa-free arrangements with the U-S consider proposals to expand their data-sharing agreements, the Australian Government is yet to clarify if they're considering the move.

item.title: US pushing for June deadline to end Russia-Ukraine war, Zelenskyy says
item.description: The US has given Ukraine and Russia a June deadline to reach a deal to end the nearly four‑year war.

item.title: 'Twisted wreck': Fresh warnings to e-bike riders found breaking rules in NSW
item.description: After a video showing e-bike riders speeding across the Sydney Harbour Bridge, police will have more powers to destroy illegal devices.

item.title: 'Spreads like wildfire': Why measles cases are on the rise and what we should do about it
item.description: Rising international travel and vaccine fatigue are among the factors behind rising measles infection rates, experts say.

item.title: 'We trust each other': Coalition reunited after Ley, Littleproud strike fresh deal
item.description: The leaders of the Nationals and Liberals say the current Coalition team will go to the next election.

item.title: Residents told 'too late to leave' as Tropical Cyclone Mitchell nears WA coast
item.description: Locals are waiting to count their losses after being hit by severe tropical Cyclone Mitchell, with the worst yet to come.

item.title: Queensland plans laws with two-year jail terms for 'from the river to the sea' slogan
item.description: Pro-Palestinian slogans would be outlawed in Queensland under sweeping legislation to crack down on hate speech and antisemitism.

item.title: Sydney pro-Palestinian protest group to launch legal challenge to Herzog visit police powers
item.description: The decision to grant police extra powers during the Israeli president's visit will face a legal challenge in the NSW Supreme Court.

item.title: 'Beyond a nuisance': Why the government is being urged to tackle sovereign citizens online
item.description: The sovereign citizen movement has become a serious security threat, and governments need to treat it as such, a new report argues.

item.title: 'Easy and cheaper': Why a growing number of Australians are adopting this niche lifestyle
item.description: Australia's off-grid communities used to be seen by some as hippy communes. These days, they're more high-tech — and a more affordable housing option.

item.title: 'Something has to happen': Pressure on Taylor to challenge Ley after Coalition reunion
item.description: A senior Liberal says the party is "now at irrelevance" after dire opinion polling, stoking fears of a leadership spill.

item.title: WA communities 'dodge a bullet' after Cyclone Mitchell weakens as it nears coast
item.description: WA Premier Roger Cook said it was "good news" the system had been downgraded to a category one, but urged locals to be vigilant.

item.title: Japan's Sanae Takaichi rides youth-led frenzy towards super majority after election win
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's governing coalition has won more than two-thirds of the lower house.

item.title: Israeli President Isaac Herzog arrives in Australia to welcome embrace and rally rage
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns declared Herzog's visit as a major event — granting police extra powers to block movement in Sydney's city centre.

item.title: Who is Michael Dickson, the Australian who just claimed Super Bowl glory?
item.description: Overlooked by the AFL, Dickson has become just the second Australian to play in and win one of the world's biggest sports events.

item.title: Australian researchers on a mission to save millions of lives from antibiotic resistance
item.description: The rise of antibiotic resistance is threatening millions of lives worldwide, but “unconventional” Australian research could make obsolete medications effective again. Data released by the World Health Organization (WHO) has found that some of the most common illnesses in the world are becoming more resistant to treatment every year. Dr Maud Eijkenboom says the current approach of developing new antibiotics is losing the battle against ever-evolving viruses and bacteria. After her son struggled with a resistant disease, Dr Eijkenboom set on her own path to discover a better way eradicate the rising wave of lethal pathogens. In 2021, she founded Lixa, a Perth-based biotech company receiving international support for its “game-changing” research. In this edition of Weekend One on One, she speaks with SBS's Cameron Carr about the impact of her research, and started by explaining what Lixa is all about.

item.title: Japan's "Iron Lady" Takaichi secures sweeping mandate for conservative agenda in landslide election
item.description: Japan's Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has won the country's election In a landslide victory, with her party expected to secure a more than two-thirds majority in the powerful lower house. Takaichi's government will push for greater defence spending, tougher immigration policies, and a stronger economy.

item.title: Minneapolis Indigenous leaders, community, hold memorial service as US Senate debates ICE funding
item.description: Indigenous leaders and community members in Minneapolis have held a memorial honouring two people shot dead by immigration officers last month. As protests against the widespread immigration crackdown continue, Republicans and Democrats remain locked in a standoff over reforms to Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The debate in the Senate continues as the deadline for reaching a funding agreement for the Department of Homeland Security looms.

item.title: Australian food causes a stir at university canteen in Germany
item.description: Students in Germany were taken aback when an unexpected dish with a decidedly Australian flavour appeared on the menu in their canteen.

item.title: Call for calm over Herzog visit | SBS News In Easy English 9 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Danish apps help grocery shoppers boycott US goods
item.description: A Danish app born out of Donald Trump’s Greenland rhetoric is turning everyday grocery shopping into a quiet act of protest. As shoppers scan products to see where their money really goes, technology, politics and consumer choice collide, revealing how global tensions can play out not in parliaments or protests, but in supermarket aisles.

item.title: 'Effectively a death sentence': Rights groups condemn Jimmy Lai's 20-year prison term
item.description: The Hong Kong pro-democracy media mogul had been found guilty on two counts of foreign collusion, to which he pleaded not guilty.

item.title: 'We will be wiped out': Support for Coalition at record low
item.description: A new opinion poll has support for the Coalition at a record low with Opposition Leader Sussan Ley the least popular leader in 23 years. The poll comes a day after she and Nationals leader David Littleproud brokered a deal to reunite the Liberal and National parties.

item.title: Extra police powers for Israeli president's visit withstand legal challenge
item.description: Protest organisers Palestine Action Group launched legal action after Isaac Herzog's visit was declared a major event.

item.title: Senate estimates wrap: AFP Herzog advice, minister's $30K phone discount and condoms
item.description: A minister's $30,000 phone bill discount has been scrutinised as Labor faces another Senate estimates week.

item.title: ASX has best day since Donald Trump's Liberation Day
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management to find out why the market has been so volatile of late as he takes a closer look at how investors will be analysing AI investments during the upcoming reporting season.

item.title: The world is running out of antibiotics. New research could make old ones work again
item.description: Australian research could be key to combating the rising threat of antibiotic resistance and saving millions of lives.

item.title: Tensions linger as protesters gather outside Sydney police station
item.description: Demonstrators gathered outside Surry Hills Police Station on Tuesday, a day after clashes with officers at Sydney's Town Hall.

item.title: Australia opposes Israel's plan to expand control in West Bank, government says
item.description: Israeli government minister Bezalel Smotrich said the changes were aimed at "burying the idea of a Palestinian state".

item.title: Roblox put on notice over 'disturbing' child grooming reports
item.description: The eSafety Commissioner has told the gaming platform it needs to take action after reports of children being targeted by predators.

item.title: Arrests made as protests against Israeli President's visit turn chaotic
item.description: Dozens of people have been arrested after a demonstration against Israel's visiting president descended into chaos. New South Wales Police say 10 of the 27 people arrested on Monday night were taken into custody for assaulting police, while witnesses have alleged that some officers were seen beating and deploying pepper spray at attendees.

item.title: Islamophobia envoy calls for apology over Sydney prayer incident; Minns defends police
item.description: Australia's Islamophobia envoy has issued a strong rebuke after NSW police officers confronted a group of men praying at a protest.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Feyza Tuncay on helping children learn about ethics
item.description: Primary Ethics is an independent, not-for-profit organisation and provides ethics classes for school students across New South Wales. Classes are impartially run by volunteers and the program has been implemented in hundreds of schools. Facilitator Feyza Tuncay became involved with Primary Ethics when she started volunteering as an ethics teacher at her son's school. She's speaking here to SBS News' Jennifer Scherer.

item.title: King Charles ready to help police with inquiries into brother Andrew, palace says
item.description: Former prince Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor has faced ongoing scrutiny over his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Hong Kong defends 20 year sentence against China critic Jimmy Lai
item.description: Hong Kong's most vocal China critic, media tycoon Jimmy Lai, has been sentenced to 20 years in prison, ending the city's largest national security case. Mr Lai's sentence on two counts of conspiracy to collude with foreign forces and one for publishing seditious materials ends a legal saga that has lasted nearly five years.

item.title: Premier Minns defends police response to rally against Herzog visit | SBS News In Easy English 10 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: DFAT admits it 'fell short' after Laos methanol poisoning victims' families left in the dark
item.description: The apology comes after the families of the victims revealed they learned of a related court case from another victim's family.

item.title: 'Speaks of colonialism': Why Bad Bunny's performance resonated around the world
item.description: Riddled with easter eggs, the show brought Puerto Rican history and culture to one of the biggest platforms on the planet.

item.title: 'Lopsided' foreign worker scheme under fire as most of the money stays in Australia
item.description: The PALM labour scheme is under renewed scrutiny after new analysis warned the program carries modern slavery risks.

item.title: Government unveils policy to end violence against First Nations women and children
item.description: The Federal Government has launched a landmark $218 million national plan to end violence against First Nations women and children. It marks the first long-term strategy designed and led entirely by Indigenous communities. While the policy targets specialised healing and emergency services in remote areas, community leaders warn that real change also requires confronting the systemic racism and high rates of violence perpetrated by non-Indigenous men.

item.title: AI industry risks and the Australian dollar nears US$0.71
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Todd Hoare from LGT Wealth Management about the day's market moves including the increasing risks AI poses to certain industries, what's driving the Australian dollar, and the opportunities for investors.

item.title: What we know about Israel's damage to Gaza cemetery housing Australian war graves
item.description: The graves include those of Australian Light Horse troops, a World War One force known for their role in the Battle of Beersheba.

item.title: Suspect detained in the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, police say
item.description: Nancy Guthrie is the mother of Melbourne-born US TV host Savannah Guthrie, and has been missing for more than a week.

item.title: Could Keir Starmer become the first world leader to lose his job over the Epstein files?
item.description: The UK prime minister is under pressure over hiring Jeffrey Epstein associate Peter Mandelson as the UK's ambassador to the US.

item.title: Albanese says he raised criminal charges over Zomi Frankcom's killing with Isaac Herzog
item.description: The prime minister said he raised Zomi Frankcom's killing in an Israeli air strike directly with the Israeli president.

item.title: Israeli minister urges protesters not to 'import conflict', defending Herzog visit
item.description: Israel's deputy foreign minister has spoken out against the "absolutely heartbreaking" violence during protests.

item.title: Israeli minister urges protesters not to 'import conflict', defending Herzog visit
item.description: Israel's deputy foreign minister has spoken out against the "absolutely heartbreaking" violence during protests.

item.title: Grand Mufti calls for transparent investigation of police conduct at Sydney rally | Midday News Bulletin 11 February 2026
item.description: The Grand Mufti of Australia calls for a transparent investigation of police conduct at a Sydney rally; the heads of America's immigration agencies questioned at a hearing in Washington; and in sport, a Ukrainian athlete defies an Olympic ban on his helmet showing war victims.

item.title: US Congress criticises ICE enforcement as 'reckless and creating chaos'
item.description: A contentious hearing of the US House Committee on Homeland Security has exposed deep divisions over immigration enforcement following the death of two American citizens at the hands of Immigration and Customs Enforcrment, better known as ICE. While ICE officials framed the deaths as a result of officers facing increasing threats of harm, the argument was rejected with those holding the agency accountable, calling its tactics Gestapo-like.

item.title: PM thanks Israeli president for providing 'comfort'; Herzog describes 'emotional' visit
item.description: Anthony Albanese has praised the Israeli president and first lady for providing comfort to Jewish Australians.

item.title: PM thanks Israeli president for providing 'comfort'; Herzog describes 'emotional' visit
item.description: Anthony Albanese has praised the Israeli president and first lady for providing comfort to Jewish Australians.

item.title: Famine levels reached in two more regions of Sudan's North Darfur, UN says
item.description: Acute malnutrition has now reached famine levels in two more regions of North Darfur in Sudan, according to a new report from a UN-backed global hunger monitor.

item.title: Eight people killed after woman opens fire at high school in Canada, suspect found dead
item.description: Police said the suspected shooter has also been found dead with "what appears to be a self‑inflicted injury".

item.title: Call for transparent investigation into police actions at Sydney rally | SBS News In Easy English 11 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Muslim worshippers say NSW police 'came in like a wrecking ball' at Sydney protest
item.description: Muslim worshippers who were praying at a Sydney protest say police intervened during a vulnerable moment of prayer.

item.title: Muslim worshippers say NSW police 'came in like a wrecking ball' at Sydney protest
item.description: Muslim worshippers who were praying at a Sydney protest say police intervened during a vulnerable moment of prayer.

item.title: Victoria Police granted extra powers ahead of Herzog visit | Evening News Bulletin 11 February 2026
item.description: Police granted extra powers ahead of the Israeli president's visit to Melbourne; Ukraine's ambassador to Australia calls for more support, as the country enters a fifth year of war.; and in football, Socceroo Mohammed Toure scores a hat-trick in his first start for Norwich City.

item.title: Review launched into the plan for Australia's largest river ecosystem
item.description: Public consultation has opened on a review into the management plan for the Murray–Darling Basin, Australia's largest river system. The announcement has come weeks after Environment Minister Murray Watt listed the lower Murray River region as critically endangered. Conservation groups have reacted cautiously, saying they hope the review leads to decisive action for a Basin that underpins public health, regional livelihoods, and cultural connection for millions.

item.title: ASIO and AFP face Senate questions about the Bondi terror attack
item.description: The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and Australian Federal Police have been questioned about their actions before and after the Bondi terror attack, with Australia's top spy agency defending its failure to prevent it. During a senate estimates hearing late on Tuesday night, the AFP also warned it will take a more aggressive approach to tackling hate and extremism.

item.title: Israel's President Herzog given official welcome in Canberra
item.description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog has enjoyed a ceremonial welcome and a lunch with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Canberra. President Herzog and his wife, Michal, were given a ceremonial 21-gun salute by the Federation Guard before attending a garden function at the Israeli embassy. His visit has been dogged by protests, with demonstrators saying he should not have been invited in the first place,

item.title: Trump allegedly said Ghislaine Maxwell is 'evil': What do we know about their relationship?
item.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney says she's prepared to speak publicly if granted clemency by the US president.

item.title: CBA's Matt Comyn on why the disruptive potential of AI should not be underestimated
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Commonwealth Bank CEO Matt Comyn following the groups $5.45bn half- year cash profit announcement, including a deep dive into artificial technology and productivity; plus Luke Laretive from Seneca Financial Solutions takes a look at the day's market action.

item.title: 'Completely over the top': How tensions built towards NSW police tactics at Sydney protest
item.description: Experts have pointed to new laws and increased police militarisation as factors leading to clashes in Sydney on Monday night.

item.title: Angus Taylor resigns ahead of an expected Liberal leadership spill | Morning News Bulletin 12 February 2026
item.description: Angus Taylor resigns ahead of an expected Liberal leadership spill; Millions of voters in Bangladesh prepare to go to the polls; And in football, Tottenham Hotspur sacks manager Thomas Frank after a poor Premier League run.

item.title: Instagram CEO defends platform against addiction claims in social media trial
item.description: The landmark trial could set a legal precedent regarding whether social media giants designed platforms to be addictive to children.

item.title: James Van Der Beek, Dawson's Creek star, dies aged 48
item.description: The American actor's family said he "passed peacefully" following a battle with cancer he disclosed in 2024.

item.title: Landmark European space launch aims to begin to challenge Elon Musk's SpaceX
item.description: On Thursday, the four-booster Ariane 64 is scheduled to lift off from French Guiana on its maiden flight. This powerful version of the Ariane 6 rocket will carry 32 satellites for Amazon Leo’s broadband constellation. At a time when the United States is seen as a potentially unreliable partner, this is a key milestone in Europe’s effort to secure independent access to space.

item.title: 'Left our nation in shock': Canada in mourning after mass shooting
item.description: Canadians are grappling with the deaths of at least nine people, including the suspect, after a mass school shooting in a remote town.

item.title: Australia to send envoy to Laos over methanol poisoning deaths, Wong announces
item.description: Australians Holly Morton-Bowles and Bianca Jones died from methanol poisoning while drinking at a backpackers' hostel in Vang Vieng.

item.title: 'Mum said go get help': Heroic 13-year-old's triple-zero call released
item.description: Police described the teenager's actions as "nothing short of extraordinary".

item.title: Angus Taylor challenges Sussan Ley for leadership of Liberal Party | Midday News Bulletin 12 February 2026
item.description: Angus Taylor challenges Sussan Ley for leadership of the Liberal Party; a special envoy appointed to progress investigations into the methanol poisoning deaths of two Australians in Laos; Australians Scotty James and Valentino Guseli reach the snowboard halfpipe final at the Milano Cortina Games.

item.title: Angus Taylor says he plans to challenge Sussan Ley for Liberal leadership | SBS News In Easy English 12 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Isaac Herzog ends his Australian trip with a visit to Melbourne | Evening News Bulletin 12 February 2026
item.description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog ends his Australian trip with a visit to Melbourne; the Liberal Party leadership to be determined in a ballot; and in cricket, Australia's T20 team makes a winning start to the World Cup in Sri Lanka against Ireland.

item.title: 'Smartest policy brain' or controversial deal-maker: Who is the real Angus Taylor?
item.description: From water dealings to questionable economic credentials — who is the new Liberal Party leader?

item.title: Angus Taylor launches leadership bid
item.description: Former Shadow Minister for Defence Angus Taylor has triggered a formal leadership challenge against Sussan Ley, prompting a wave of coordinated frontbench resignations. The coalition is reeling from historic polling lows. While Mr Taylor campaigns for a "decisive" reset of the party’s values, a loyal faction of Liberals is fighting to protect Ms Ley’s position, arguing she deserves more time to stabilise the party room before Friday’s high-stakes ballot.

item.title: Latest report on Closing the Gap targets not a story of 'failure', says PM
item.description: The federal government has released its latest report card on its Closing the Gap targets, which are meant to improve the lives of Indigenous Australians. The data shows just four of the 19 targets are on track. Anthony Albanese has used his annual closing the gap speech on Thursday to announce a $144 million boost to Indigenous health to upgrade more than 100 services in cities and regional areas. But some - like the incarceration rates of First Nations people - continue to worsen.

item.title: AMP CEO Alexis George on results, super changes and female leadership
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with AMP CEO Alexis George following the financial services company's full-year results as she prepares to step down, including her advice to aspiring female leaders; plus Stephanie Youssef discusses the day's market action with market analyst Evan Lucas.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s ‘death’ sentence, Japan’s Takaichi takes on China & the bulging Olympic controversy
item.description: A massive win for Japan’s hawkish first female PM worries China, conservatives reclaim Thailand and Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong’s most high-profile casualty of draconian security laws gets a ‘death sentence’. Plus, trouble growing at the winter Olympics.

item.title: The results of recent Liberal spills show a clear trend. What does it mean for Angus Taylor?
item.description: Sussan Ley is fighting to defy the odds when it comes to leadership challenges in her party.

item.title: Israeli president wraps up visit feeling 'hope in the air' — and with a message to protesters
item.description: Isaac Herzog's trip has sparked controversy and national protests, including a Sydney rally that descended into violence on Monday.

item.title: Pat is living in a 'dangerous' and run-down home. They've been hit with a rent increase
item.description: Across Australia, rents are climbing far faster than wages and many can't keep up.

item.title: Further protests mark end of Israeli President’s Australia visit | Morning News Bulletin 13 February 2026
item.description: Thousands in Melbourne protest against Israeli president's visit to Australia; Angus Taylor expected to challenge for the Liberal leadership today; And in sport, the IOC bans a Ukrainian skeleton racer over a tribute helmet.

item.title: Immigration crackdown in Minnesota to end, US border chief announces
item.description: Border tsar Tom Homan said Donald Trump had agreed to end the operation, which saw 3,000 armed immigration agents deployed to the state.

item.title: 'Something you dream of': Cooper Woods claims gold, Australia's first medal at Milano Cortina Winter Olympics
item.description: The 25-year-old was up against all-time greats Mikaël Kingsbury of Canada and Japan's Ikuma Horishima, but rose to the occasion.

item.title: Angus Taylor has outlined his priorities after ousting Sussan Ley as Liberal leader
item.description: A new Liberal Party duo has emerged, with Angus Taylor becoming its 17th leader.

item.title: ICE's controversial surge force to quit Minnesota
item.description: The United States' border chief has announced ICE agents will withdraw from Minnesota. This ends a two-month surge operation which resulted in two US citizens being killed by federal agents, and thousands of arrests. It follows mass protests in the state and across the country, as well as condemnation by Democratic Senators over the violent immigration crackdown.

item.title: Angus Taylor elected new Liberal Party leader after spill motion | Midday News Bulletin 13 February 2026
item.description: Angus Taylor elected new leader of the Liberal Party, after winning a spill motion; advocates call for urgent action on Indigenous deaths in custody; and in hockey, Australia's Kookaburras secure their second win of the FIH Pro League Hobart block.

item.title: NSW police to be investigated over protest, as witness shares new account of 'dark moment'
item.description: The Law Enforcement Conduct Commission said it had received a "significant number of complaints" about police conduct at Monday's rally.

item.title: Angus Taylor elected new Liberal Party leader | SBS News In Easy English 13 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: What is the secret to an elephant's grace? Whiskers
item.description: While the whiskers on a cat might be known to help them balance and detect their surroundings, scientists have discovered elephants have super whiskers too. Around 1,000 whiskers cover their trunks, giving them a sense of touch that compensates for their thick skin and poor eyesight. Researchers in Germany are now working to translate the elephant's sensitive touch to robotic science.

item.title: "There's not a lot left to burn": Coalition launches new bid for unity and support under Angus Taylor
item.description: Angus Taylor has seized the Liberal Party leadership in a decisive party room vote - 34 to 17 - ending Sussan Ley’s nine-month tenure as the party’s first female leader. Backed by new deputy Jane Hume, the Rhodes scholar and former Shadow Treasurer now faces the challenge of rebuilding a fractured base while navigating a political history marked by significant past controversies.

item.title: Lunar New Year 2026: What to know about the 'very special' Year of the Fire Horse
item.description: The fire horse, which occurs once every 60 years, is considered to be like "double fire".

item.title: New Liberal leader Angus Taylor vows to restore living standards | Evening News Bulletin 13 February 2026
item.description: New Liberal leader Angus Taylor vows to restore living standards as a policy focus; Stolen Generations survivors reflect on 18 years since the National Apology; and in sport, the Socceroos announce their base camp for their World Cup games in the US.

item.title: ANZ says AUD heading for US $0.73 as Cochlear warns of currency impacts
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Cochlear CEO Dig Howett about the hearing implant maker's latest results, the link between hearing loss and dementia and the impact the higher Australian dollar will have on its earnings. Plus Mahjabeen Zaman from ANZ looks at the drivers of the surging currency and market implications.

item.title: SBS NITV Radio talks to Charles Pakana about World Radio Day
item.description: 13 February is celebrated as World Radio Day. The day is designed to honour radio as a trusted and powerful form of communication. Today is also the 18th anniversary of the National Apology to the Stolen Generations. SBS NITV Radio's Kerri-Lee Barry has spoken to Charles Pakana from Victorian Aboriginal News, who says radio is a way to connect with each other as we share our histories and truth.

item.title: Bangladesh's election winners take sweeping majority in crucial post-uprising vote
item.description: The Bangladesh Nationalist Party has won the country's first election since a 2024 uprising, claiming a two-thirds majority after months of political turmoil.

item.title: Two UK men sentenced over plot to target Jewish community | Morning News Bulletin 14 February 2026
item.description: Two men jailed in England for plotting an IS-inspired terror attack on Jewish community; More heavy rain forecast for South East Queensland; and a State of Origin revival in the AFL.

item.title: Australians' personal data could soon be accessible by US agencies. Here's why
item.description: Speculation over a proposal to hand Australians' biometric data to the US is raising concerns among privacy experts.

item.title: 'Not a Ley problem': The long-standing Liberal issues that may haunt Angus Taylor
item.description: Among several issues that plagued Sussan Ley, one broke "the camel's back", turning voters to One Nation, a polling expert says.

item.title: The Lunar New Year DIY dumpling event putting a new spin on a centuries-old tradition
item.description: Dumplings are popular dish for families celebrating Lunar New Year. In Melbourne, one restaurant is challenging tradition, with a make-your-own approach and a range of exotic flavours.

item.title: Brisbane lion dancers master their skills to welcome the Year of the Horse
item.description: Millions of people around the world will soon welcome in the Year of the Horse. A key part of Lunar New Year celebrations for many communities is lion dancing, which is said to bring good luck and prosperity into the new year. But it takes discipline to master the skill, as one group of dancers in Brisbane hopes to continue the traditional performance

item.title: Tears of joy as snowboarder Josie Baff scores Australia's second Winter Olympics gold
item.description: Baff knew fellow Aussie gold medalist Cooper Woods growing up, and said his victory a day earlier "sparked a little fire in me".

item.title: The introduction of decimal currency, 60 years on
item.description: Today marks a major milestone in Australia’s financial history – the 60th anniversary of decimal currency. It’s been decades since Australians ditched pounds, shillings and pence for dollars and cents – in one of the largest transitions in the nation’s history. And while the way we pay for things continues to change, the legacy of that moment endures.

item.title: Bondi attack stories and memories to be preserved in new digital project
item.description: The Sydney Jewish Museum has asked people to share memories through an online tool, and hoped the project would "amplify healing".

item.title: Gary wasn't impressed by Australia's dumpling scene. Now he's selling thousands a day
item.description: Dumplings are a popular dish for Lunar New Year celebrations. However, one Australian restaurant is bringing a twist to the tradition.

item.title: PM calls for 'full explanation' after Muslim prayer disrupted by police at Sydney protest
item.description: Anthony Albanese said the Muslim community was feeling a "great deal of hurt" after officers manhandled several worshippers.

item.title: US ramps up pressure on Iran, deploys additional carrier strike group | Midday News Bulletin 14 February 2026
item.description: US ramps up pressure on Iran, deploys additional carrier strike group; Anthony Albanese seeks answers over police conduct at Sydney protest, criticises organisers; And in sport, injured snowboarder Cam Bolton to be medically transported home to Australia.

item.title: Mariam's story of survival amid a 'war on women' in Sudan
item.description: Nearly three years into a civil war, Sudan is facing a hunger crisis. It's also facing a crisis of violence against women.

item.title: 'Can a souffle rise once?': Albanese takes first swipe at new Opposition leaders
item.description: The prime minister has made his first comments about the ouster of Sussan Ley.

item.title: Anthony Albanese comments on the Liberals leadership spill | Evening News Bulletin 14 February 2026
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese comments on the Liberals leadership spill, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney joins vigil for victims of a mass shooting, Australia's snowboard great Scotty James vows for a comeback after winning silver at Milan-Cortina Games...

item.title: Bangladesh's Tarique Rahman poised to be PM as Islamists concede in 'credible' elections
item.description: Nearly 60% turned up to vote in what the Bangladesh Electoral Commission called "by far, the best election" in the country.

item.title: Bangladesh's Tarique Rahman poised to be PM as Islamists concede in 'credible' elections
item.description: Nearly 60% turned up to vote in what the Bangladesh Electoral Commission called "by far, the best election" in the country.

item.title: With their first female leader gone, can the Liberals shake their 'women problem'?
item.description: Senior Liberals say Sussan Ley’s removal was about polling, not gender. But experts warn it may reinforce doubts about the party’s appeal to women.

item.title: Injured Aussie aerials champion ruled out of Olympics
item.description: Australia's two-time aerials world champion Laura Peel is the fourth Australian to withdraw from the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics.

item.title: More calls for stronger action against Russia at Munich conference | Morning News Bulletin 15 February 2026
item.description: More calls for stronger action against Russia at the Munich Security Conference; An aid group suspends operations in a major Gaza hospital; and in sport, a third gold medal makes the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics Australia's most-successful ever.

item.title: Stressed about Lunar New Year? Here are tips to look after your mental health
item.description: From dinner-table arguments to loneliness, experts weigh in on some of the challenges families can face during the Lunar New Year.

item.title: How a hair stylist's client list became a campaign to change surrogacy laws
item.description: Jay always wanted to be a dad, but WA's surrogacy laws meant significant barriers. So he became the face of a campaign to change them.

item.title: Mariam's story of survival amid a 'war on women' in Sudan
item.description: Women and girls are bearing the brunt of Sudan’s nearly three-year-old civil war, facing widespread gender-based violence, displacement and deepening hunger as the conflict intensifies. 18-year-old Mariam, a survivor of sexual violence has had to flee escalating violence to an under-resourced displacement camp where food and medicine is in limited supply. With famine spreading and humanitarian access shrinking, organisations like Plan International warn the needs of survivors far exceed the support available.

item.title: INTERVIEW: What needs to happen to bring the Murray Darling Basin back to health?
item.description: The Murray Darling Basin management plan is currently under review. Public submissions on a discussion paper [[see it here: https://www.mdba.gov.au/publications-and-data/publications/2026-basin-plan-review-discussion-paper]] are being accepted until 1 May 2026, as authorities determine their next steps in managing Australia's biggest river ecosystem. SBS has spoken with the national director of the Murray Darling Conservation Alliance, Craig Wilkins, about what those next steps should be.

item.title: 'Unprecedented times': Jakara Anthony's Olympic gold secures record medal haul for Australia
item.description: The 27-year-old skier has become Australia's first ever two-time Winter Olympic gold medallist.

item.title: Russia poisoned Alexei Navalny with frog toxin, UK and European allies say
item.description: The Putin critic was killed by a "lethal toxin" found on the skin of a South American dart frog, according to five European states.
